description.narrative: Identifying opportunities for water efficiency in South African industriesIn the middle of the global climate crisis, water security is one of the biggest challenges of South Africa. Many companies depend on water for their daily operations and need to make an effort to use water more efficiently.After Cape Town nearly reaching ‘Day Zero’, researchers have warned that South Africa’s economic heart, the Gauteng city region (Johannesburg, Pretoria), is reaching its limits of existing water supply. The gap between water supply and water demand for its increasing population is becoming a severe issue. Though Gauteng has half of the global average rainfall, it consumes almost double the global average on a per capita basis of 300 liters a day.In the major cities, the industry uses about 16% of the available water. Business is severely at risk of secure water supply and has a key role to play in reducing water demand as well as increasing water quality.However, since water is cheap, it is not always considered as a scarce resource and not valued that way by local industries. Commercial banks are not looking to water as an operational risk, and development banks (e.g. FMO, DFCD through Climate Fund Managers) cannot find bankable water projects to invest in. This hampers innovation in the water sector, while there is a lot of low-hanging fruit in terms of efficiency gains. The Netherlands is one of the most water efficient countries in the world and has a lot of innovative solutions on offer. Therefore, the Netherlands works together with the South African ‘National Business Initiative’ (NBI), a voluntary coalition of SA and multinational companies, working towards sustainable growth and development in SA, to:-Assist South Africa to identify opportunities for investing in water efficiency, re-use and quality solutions. NBI will identify industries in Gauteng who want to work on water efficiency, re-use and quality)-Reach industry and related stakeholders to promote the valuing water principles and bring together stakeholders from government, cities, industry business and financing. - make matches between Dutch innovators and South African demand for technology and financing
